content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: As a beginner in Python, it was interesting to learn how to sort a string without case sensitivity. It's pretty easy, though somewhat uncommon.
Would the author please follow up the issues raised in previous comments? Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Complex challenge that can still be understood and solved in less than 5 minutes.
This is appropriately challenging and the description is clear.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The contribution is concise and challenging. Well done!

Hello,
I discovered your contribution today, I don't know if you have modified the description since the last comments, but as it stands I find it well balanced, just what is needed to challenge.

I think it would be beneficial for the people solving this problem if you utilized variables, constants, etc. in your problem description. This would improve its readability.

Also try adding a test with an input string of length one or two and a test case with an input string that doesn't change when deciphered (i.e. the code is in numeric order). Special characters or spaces in the puzzle input is also a good idea.

Overall, its a good clash and is certain to engage even the best of programmers.

Maybe write or explain the full process:
1. Sorting: oCed ➡ Cdeo
2. Apply pattern: 1➡C 4➡o 2➡d 3➡e
So "oCed 1423" becomes "Code".

Do not speak about Capital, maybe just use "ASCII order"

I do not know the real-life use of this coding, the only "hidden" part is to know that you need to order the letters first (and so in order to cypher a word, you need to note the letters positions when sorted, then scramble the letters)

It is currently not clear how to decipher the code. I think you're applying some kind of permutation, but that's all I can gather. Please state exactly and in detail how you go about getting from the input to the output.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: The statement says "(Capitals are ranked higher than lower case)" but the solution provided and the tests/validators don't follow the rule and instead ignore case when sorting. If the capital letters ranked higher, we would expect them to be at the end of the sorted word.

I think you have misinterpreted the description. What I meant to say is that if there are two duplicate letters, the capital letter will come first. Would you have any ideas on how to make the description less ambiguous? I would like to make the description as clear as possible.

"Two duplicate letters" vs "capital letter will come first": If there are duplicate letters, they should be the same...?

**********************

The logic is just confusing.

Take Validator 1 as an example:

Do we put the uppercase letters first? No. Otherwise, it would have been something like VRalidato.

Do we put the lowercase letters first? No. Otherwise, it would have been something like alidatoVR.

Do we sort the letters in descending order of the corresponding ranking (digits)? No. Otherwise, it would have been something like VdiltoaRa.

Do we sort the letters in ascending order of the corresponding ranking (digits)? No. Otherwise, it would have been something like aRaotlidV.

You'll have to explain your logic with an explanation of one of the cases first.

In Validator 3, formM is alphabetically arranged such that it shows fMmor. When the two letters are  the same "m and M", the capital M will go before the lowercase m. 
After it is alphabetically sorted, the second input describes the order. In the example I showed previously, the pattern is 21345. Since "M" is the second letter in "fMmor", it is displayed first. "f" is the first letter so it  is displayed next. Then the third, fourth, and finally fifth. Leading to the output: Mfmor
I hope this resolves your issue. I will try to make my actual description easier to understand.

It looks clearer now, but please avoid the confusing description of "duplicate letters" and "ranked higher". I'd suggest to write instead:
if there are both the uppercase and the lowercase of a letter, the uppercase comes before the lowercase,

Please also format the following as {{constants}} and remove all the quotation marks:
* cabBc
* aBbcc
* JAva
* AaJv
* 4132
* v
* A
* J
* a
* vAJa

Thanks.
